It is related with German rein (â€œpureâ€), Gothic ğŒ·ğ‚ğŒ°ğŒ¹ğŒ½ğƒ (hrains, â€œcleanâ€), and English riddle. The Latin verb is related to recent.

examples: I'll just give this knife a quick rinse.

entries.meaning: A liquid used to rinse, now particularly a hair dye.
examples: I had a henna rinse yesterday.

verbs.description: rinse (third-person singular simple present rinses, present participle rinsing, simple past and past participle rinsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wash (something) quickly using water and no soap.
examples: You'd better rinse that stain before putting the shirt in the washing machine.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove soap from (something) using water.
examples: Rinse the dishes after you wash them.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang) To thoroughly defeat in an argument, fight or other competition.
